node_title: Claude Code 1.0.9 no longer reports the costUSD field
bodyText:
This only happens in opus model. Here is the summary by Claude Code:
⏺ Looking at the conversation history and the current state of the codebase, I can see that:

  1. The initial issue where bun ./index.ts -s 20250603 showed tokens but zero cost has been fixed by correcting the schema to place the model field
  inside the message object.
  2. A verification script was created that revealed:
    - 83.34% of entries with both costUSD and model match the new calculations
    - 16.66% show mismatches, all with exactly 2x difference
    - All mismatches are for the claude-opus-4-20250514 model
    - This indicates the pricing for this model has doubled since the original calculations
  3. The verification script has been kept as requested and shows detailed results including model-by-model breakdowns.

  The user's requests have been completed:
  - The bug was fixed
  - The pricing verification was performed
  - The verification script was kept
  - Full results were shown

  The codebase is now working correctly with the fixed schema and can handle both old entries (with pre-calculated costUSD) and new entries (with model
  field for dynamic cost calculation).
As far as my understanding, the price hasn't changed

bodyText: What is it? Could you show us the doc on it?

node_title: Enhancement: fetchModelPricing support HTTPS_PROXY
bodyText:
Hi, here's a write-up for http proxy and example in python, I'm not familiar with ts/js so I'm not sure what's the equivalence
HTTP Proxy in Corporate Environments
What is HTTP Proxy?
An HTTP proxy sits between clients and servers, forwarding requests/responses. Corporate environments use proxies for:

Security: Filter malicious content and unauthorized websites
Monitoring: Log network traffic for compliance
Access Control: Block specific domains or content
Bandwidth: Cache content to reduce external traffic

Environment Variables
HTTP_PROXY=http://proxy.company.com:8080
HTTPS_PROXY=http://proxy.company.com:8080
NO_PROXY=localhost,127.0.0.1,.company.com
Python Example
import requests

# Method 1: Explicit proxy
proxies = {'http': 'http://proxy.company.com:8080', 'https': 'http://proxy.company.com:8080'}
response = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/ip', proxies=proxies)

# Method 2: Environment variables (preferred)
import os
os.environ['HTTPS_PROXY'] = 'http://proxy.company.com:8080'
response = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/ip')  # Auto-uses proxy

node_title: ccusage fails when LiteLLM API is unavailable
bodyText:
Finally, by cloning the code locally and having Claude Code analyze it, I discovered the real cause of the problem. It is essentially still a network issue (mainland China network restrictions). Although I configured a proxy, it seems that for some reason the proxy cannot be used. The following is the resolution process organized by AI:
Problem
When running ccusage, encountered network connection error:
ERROR Failed to fetch model pricing: fetch failed
The tool was unable to access the LiteLLM pricing API at:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BerriAI/litellm/main/model_prices_and_
context_window.json
Root Cause

Node.js v22.12.0 fetch API had connectivity issues in certain network
environments
Local proxy settings (https_proxy=http://127.0.0.1:8888) interfered
with the request
The issue persisted even when proxy environment variables were
disabled

Solution
Modified the pricing URL to use a GitHub mirror service:
Original URL:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BerriAI/litellm/main/model_prices_and_context_window.json
Mirror URL:
https://ghfast.top/https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BerriAI/litellm/main/model_prices_and_context_window.json
Code Change:
In src/pricing-fetcher.ts, line 14:
const LITELLM_PRICING_URL =
"https://ghfast.top/https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BerriAI/litellm/
main/model_prices_and_context_window.json";
Result

✅ Successfully loads 1053+ model pricing entries
✅ All ccusage functionality works normally
✅ No changes needed to the core logic

Alternative Workarounds
For users experiencing similar issues:

Use --mode display to bypass network requests entirely
Use --mode calculate only when network access is available
Consider adding configurable mirror URL support for different regions

node_title: 5 hours sessions tracker
bodyText:
Hi @ryoppippi and @a-c-m,
My apologies for the duplicate PR. After reviewing the technical specifications more carefully, I realize that PR #80's approach with dynamic 5-hour windows starting from first message is the correct implementation of Claude's session tracking.
My PR #84 incorrectly uses fixed UTC time windows, which doesn't match how Claude actually counts sessions. @a-c-m's implementation properly follows the rolling 5-hour window specification.
I'll close my PR since #80 has the correct approach. Great work @a-c-m!
Thanks for your patience with the confusion.

node_title: 5 hours sessions tracker
bodyText:
📋 Technical Reference: Claude Session Tracking Specification
For anyone implementing session tracking, here are the key technical points from my research:
Session Definition:

Sessions are 5-hour rolling windows starting from first message (NOT fixed time slots like 00:00-05:00)
Cross-platform: sessions span ALL Claude interfaces (web, mobile, Claude Code) with shared quota
Example: Message at 09:00 starts session until 14:00; next message at 14:01 starts new session

Critical Implementation Challenges:

Claude Code alone provides incomplete data - can't track web/mobile usage
Monthly reset period unclear: calendar month vs billing cycle (needs Anthropic clarification)
Max plan: 50 sessions/month limit (flexible guideline, ~250 hours potential)

Accurate Implementation Requirements:

Monitor ALL Claude platforms (currently impossible with local data only)
Track exact timestamps of first message in each 5-hour window
Handle cross-conversation sessions within same window

Note: This is my interpretation of available docs - could be wrong! For accurate specs, you'd need to contact Anthropic support directly.
Any CLI implementation should clearly state limitations and encourage users to verify actual usage via claude.ai/settings.

node_title: removing object.groupBy because node.js 20 doesn't have
bodyText:
@ryoppippi
Thank you for assigning this task!
I investigated the tsdown target approach you suggested, but unfortunately it didn't work as expected.
I've created a detailed investigation report and would love your feedback on the next steps.
Conclusion
The tsdown target configuration doesn't resolve the Object.groupBy compatibility issue for Node.js 20, as it only handles syntax transformations, not runtime API polyfills.

Detailed Investigation Report
What I Tested
1. Package.json engines approach
Following tsdown's default target behavior, I added:
{
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=20.0.0"
  }
}
Result: tsdown automatically detected this and set target: node20.0.0, but Object.groupBy remained untranspiled.
2. Runtime helpers approach
Following tsdown's runtime helpers documentation, I added @oxc-project/runtime to provide runtime helpers when downleveling features.
Result: While the package was installed successfully, Object.groupBy still wasn't polyfilled. Looking at the OXC runtime helpers source, there's no array-grouping helper, so this feature likely isn't supported.
3. Testing across Node.js versions
I used volta to test the built output across different Node.js versions:
# Node.js 22.16.0 - Works fine
❯ node -v
v22.16.0
❯ node dist/index.js daily
# Successfully displays usage report

# Node.js 20.19.2 - Object.groupBy error
❯ volta pin node@20
❯ node -v  
v20.19.2
❯ node dist/index.js daily
TypeError: Object.groupBy is not a function
Root Cause
The issue is that tsdown's target option only affects syntax transformations (like async/await, arrow functions), not runtime API polyfills. As stated in the documentation:

"The target option only affects syntax transformations. It does not include runtime polyfills or shims for APIs that may not exist in the target environment."

Since Object.groupBy is a runtime API introduced in Node.js 21, it requires explicit polyfilling for Node.js 20 compatibility.

Proposed Solutions
a. Polyfill package approach
Use the object.groupby npm package which provides an ES3-compatible polyfill:
npm install object.groupby
Then import it at the top of files that use Object.groupBy.
b. Manual implementation
Replace Object.groupBy usage with a custom implementation (similar to your original PR approach), which avoids external dependencies.
My Opinion
I'm leaning toward option (a) - the polyfill package approach. While it adds a dependency, it's a well-maintained, standardized implementation that will automatically work if Node.js versions change, and it keeps the code clean by using the standard API.
If you have any other ideas or preferred approaches, I'd love to hear them! Once we decide on the solution, I'd be happy to help implement it 🚀

node_title: Hitting error on installation
bodyText:
Consider upgrading Node.js to 18.18 or higher... you can throw the error into your favorite LLM but here's what I got:
Why you’re seeing TypeError: Object is not disposable


ccusage 0.7.0 was compiled with the new “Explicit Resource Management” (ERM) feature of JavaScript / TypeScript
ERM introduces the using / await using keywords and the two well-known symbols Symbol.dispose and Symbol.asyncDispose.
At runtime every value that appears in a using statement must expose a function under Symbol.dispose; otherwise the helper function in the bundle throws
TypeError("Object is not disposable."). This is exactly the line blowing up in the generated file you pasted.


Your Node version (v18 .17.0) does not yet provide the Symbol.dispose built-in
Support for Symbol.dispose and Symbol.asyncDispose first shipped in Node 18 .18.0 and is, of course, present in all newer lines (20 .x LTS and 24 .x Current). When the symbol is missing the ERM polyfill inside esbuild/ccusage can’t wire things up correctly, so the helper decides the object “is not disposable” and aborts.


esbuild’s polyfill has a known quirk that shows up on runtimes missing the symbol
The issue was reported upstream: esbuild falls back to Symbol.for('Symbol.dispose'), but if the global doesn’t exist the helper still fails later, giving the identical stack trace you saw.


How to fix it (pick one)



Fix
What to do




Upgrade Node (recommended)
nvm install 20 (or 18.20.0+) then nvm use 20.The CLI works out of the box on Node ≥ 18 .18 because the symbols are present.


Stay on Node 18 .17 but polyfill
Before running ccusage, add one line in a bootstrap script:js\nglobalThis.Symbol.dispose ??= Symbol.for('Symbol.dispose');\n…and run the CLI through node -r ./polyfill.js $(npm bin)/ccusage ….(Only worth it if you’re pinned to that exact Node minor.)


Use an older CLI build
npx ccusage@0.6.3 – the last version that didn’t rely on ERM.



Extra tips


After upgrading Node you’ll probably want to update npm as the notice suggests (npm i -g npm@11).


The ERM feature is moving quickly; if you keep auto-updating ccusage you’ll avoid these mismatches by also keeping your Node runtime on the latest LTS.


That should get npx ccusage running cleanly again—let me know if you hit anything else!

node_title: Live usage progress bars don't seem to reflect actual limit?
bodyText:
Burn rate is correlated with time, so it should be updated even if the CC is idle — because time is still passing. The more time spent idle, the lower the burn rate.
For example:

In the first minute, 100 tokens are used → burn rate = 100 tokens/min.
The second minute is idle (no additional usage) → total usage = 100 tokens over 2 minutes → average burn rate = 50 tokens/min.

So if we calculate the average burn rate since the monitor was launched or since the latest block started, it must factor in idle time to reflect real usage speed.

node_title: Request for Clarification on Token Calculation for the `blocks` Command
bodyText:
The issue here is simply that the total tokens are being calculated incorrectly:
// blocks JSON output
totalTokens: block.tokenCounts.inputTokens + block.tokenCounts.outputTokens,

// daily
totalTokens: getTotalTokens(block.tokenCounts)

My understanding is that the intention behind all total token counts is that they include all token types.
This inconsistency was also the case elsewhere in the project; I have just fixed a couple of other instances in a PR. I will open a separate PR for this issue.

node_title: Tracking token usage in sub-tasks
bodyText:
I dont know if this can help.
When working on my statusline, I asked claude to show me the total token used for the current session, including tokens used from agents. It created a bash script with this calculations and seems to work pretty well
#!/bin/bash

# Read JSON input
input=$(cat)

# Check if jq is available
if ! command -v jq &> /dev/null; then
    echo "Claude Code | Working | 📝 -- tokens"
    exit 0
fi

# Extract model name
model=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.model.display_name // .model.id // "Unknown"' 2>/dev/null)
if [[ -z "$model" || "$model" == "null" ]]; then
    model="Claude Code"
fi

# Color code based on model (ANSI color codes)
# Opus = Cyan (36), Sonnet = Orange (33), Haiku = Green (32), Unknown = White
model_colored="$model"
if [[ "$model" == *"Opus"* ]] || [[ "$model" == *"opus"* ]]; then
    model_colored="\033[1;36m$model\033[0m"  # Cyan for Opus
elif [[ "$model" == *"Sonnet"* ]] || [[ "$model" == *"sonnet"* ]]; then
    model_colored="\033[38;5;208m$model\033[0m"  # True orange for Sonnet (256 color)
elif [[ "$model" == *"Haiku"* ]] || [[ "$model" == *"haiku"* ]]; then
    model_colored="\033[1;32m$model\033[0m"  # Green for Haiku
else
    model_colored="\033[1;37m$model\033[0m"  # White for unknown
fi

# Extract project directory and get project name
project_dir=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.workspace.project_dir // .workspace.current_dir // ""' 2>/dev/null)
if [[ -n "$project_dir" ]] && [[ "$project_dir" != "null" ]]; then
    # Convert Windows path to Unix format
    project_dir="${project_dir//\\//}"
    project_name=$(basename "$project_dir")
else
    project_name="Working"
fi

# Get total tokens from transcript
total_tokens="0"
transcript_path=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.transcript_path // ""' 2>/dev/null)
if [[ -n "$transcript_path" ]] && [[ "$transcript_path" != "null" ]]; then
    # Convert Windows path to Unix format for Git Bash
    transcript_path="${transcript_path//\\//}"
    
    if [[ -f "$transcript_path" ]]; then
        # Sum up all tokens from usage fields (including subagent tokens)
        input_tokens=$(grep -o '"input_tokens":[0-9]*' "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null | grep -o '[0-9]*' | awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}')
        output_tokens=$(grep -o '"output_tokens":[0-9]*' "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null | grep -o '[0-9]*' | awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}')
        
        # Cache tokens are typically free/discounted, so we track them separately
        cache_creation=$(grep -o '"cache_creation_input_tokens":[0-9]*' "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null | grep -o '[0-9]*' | awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}')
        cache_read=$(grep -o '"cache_read_input_tokens":[0-9]*' "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null | grep -o '[0-9]*' | awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}')
        
        # Also look for subagent token usage (they might be in different fields)
        # Check for "total_tokens" field which might include subagent usage
        total_tokens_field=$(grep -o '"total_tokens":[0-9]*' "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null | grep -o '[0-9]*' | awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}')
        
        # Look for subagent specific patterns (like "agent_tokens", "task_tokens", etc.)
        agent_tokens=$(grep -o '"agent.*tokens":[0-9]*\|"task.*tokens":[0-9]*\|"sub.*tokens":[0-9]*' "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null | grep -o '[0-9]*' | awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}')
        
        # Calculate total
        input_tokens=${input_tokens:-0}
        output_tokens=${output_tokens:-0}
        cache_creation=${cache_creation:-0}
        cache_read=${cache_read:-0}
        total_tokens_field=${total_tokens_field:-0}
        agent_tokens=${agent_tokens:-0}
        
        # Calculate cache total
        cache_total=$((cache_creation + cache_read))
        
        # Use the maximum of calculated or reported total
        # NOT including cache tokens as they don't count against the plan
        calculated_total=$((input_tokens + output_tokens + agent_tokens))
        if [[ $total_tokens_field -gt $calculated_total ]]; then
            total_tokens=$total_tokens_field
        else
            total_tokens=$calculated_total
        fi
    fi
fi

# Format tokens with thousand separator
if [[ "$total_tokens" =~ ^[0-9]+$ ]]; then
    # Add thousand separator (.) to the number
    total_tokens=$(echo "$total_tokens" | sed ':a;s/\B[0-9]\{3\}\>/\.&/;ta')
fi

# Format cache tokens with thousand separator
cache_display=""
if [[ $cache_total -gt 0 ]]; then
    # Add thousand separator (.) to the cache number
    cache_formatted=$(echo "$cache_total" | sed ':a;s/\B[0-9]\{3\}\>/\.&/;ta')
    # Gray color for cached tokens (color code 90) - no parentheses
    cache_display=" \033[90m${cache_formatted} cached\033[0m"
fi

# Output the status line with colored model and cache info
# Project name in yellow (33)
printf "%b | \033[1;33m%s\033[0m | 📝 %s tk%b\n" "$model_colored" "$project_name" "$total_tokens" "$cache_display"

node_title: In `ccusage blocks --live`, the maximum value of the "USAGE" gauge is too large, so even when you hit the limit quickly, the gauge progress doesn't advance much
bodyText:
Because the limits of Claude code are not well-defined, the default operation of this mode is to use the largest usage block you have ever had as the limit. This means that, for the first screenshot in the OP, at some point you have had a block where you used 223095k tokens. The fact that you have hit the limit with fewer tokens than this tells us that Anthropic has indeed reduced the limit recently.
You can supply a limit on the CLI which overrides the "largest" value. My suggestion based on the above screenshots would be that this is set to around 75,000,000 tokens, to be safe.

node_title: In `ccusage blocks --live`, the maximum value of the "USAGE" gauge is too large, so even when you hit the limit quickly, the gauge progress doesn't advance much
bodyText:
Because the limits of Claude code are not well-defined, the default operation of this mode is to use the largest usage block you have ever had as the limit. This means that, for the first screenshot in the OP, at some point you have had a block where you used 223095k tokens. The fact that you have hit the limit with fewer tokens than this tells us that Anthropic has indeed reduced the limit recently.
You can supply a limit on the CLI which overrides the "largest" value. My suggestion based on the above screenshots would be that this is set to around 75,000,000 tokens, to be safe.

Thanks for the valuable information! Based on my understanding, the freshness of data is key here. After using Claude Code for months, the all-time maximum usage value becomes outdated and no longer reflects current limits.
Looking at my personal needs, what I want is a clearer way to track how close I am to hitting the limit—something more intuitive than Claude Code's existing UI. This is where ccusage's USAGE gauge comes in handy.
Here's my proposed solution: When we hit the most recent USAGE LIMIT, store the token count from that block as the latest observed limit. If any subsequent block uses significantly more tokens than this observed limit, we could update our estimated limit, as Anthropic may have dynamically adjusted the thresholds.
This would give us both observed and estimated limit values. Personally, I think having multiple threshold markers on a single gauge could work well. However, it's worth noting that usage through the web UI (like https://claude.ai/new) also counts toward the limit, so no value will be perfectly reliable.
I might take a stab at creating a pull request for this with vibe coding (no promises though!).

node_title: Monitoring Shared Usage Limits Across Claude and Claude Code
bodyText:
That would be a great feature, but unfortunately it's not currently possible. The ccusage tool works by scanning local JSONL files that contain detailed usage data generated specifically by Claude Code. Since we don't have access to the cloud-based usage data from the web interface, there's no way to combine both sources to provide a complete picture of your total usage across both platforms.

node_title: [OOM bug] ccusage need a cache for claude code /statusline
bodyText:
we disable fetching api, but it is not enough? we need to configure refresh rate at least

Claude code will call the statusline tool once a second, so every time ccusage grabs the PRICE API, it will cause a freeze.
If ccusage can cache the results for 60 seconds in the /tmp directory, then ccusage will be a good fit for Claude code.
Of course, if ccusage can only fetch the API price once a day and cache the result, it might be possible to call ccusage once per second without lag. I haven't tested this yet.

node_title: [Bug] ccusage statusline causes infinite process spawning loop leading to 100% CPU usage
[Bug] ccusage statusline causes infinite process spawning loop leading to 100% CPU usage
bodyText:
Issue: Memory leak causing 20+ Node.js processes when used as Claude
Code status line
Environment:

Windows 11
Claude Code with global ccusage installation
Status line config: "command": "bun x ccusage statusline"

Problem:

ccusage installed globally via npm install -g ccusage@15.9.2
Claude Code shell snapshot corruption - creates infinite recursive
shell execution loops
Multiple Node.js processes spawn (up to 20+ simultaneously,
150MB-600MB each)
Memory consumption escalates to several GB
ccusage persists even after uninstall - keeps respawning via cached
global Claude Code settings

Root Cause:

ccusage status line command triggers Claude Code's shell snapshot
system
Shell snapshots become corrupted, creating recursive execution paths
like:
/c/Users/tommy/.claude/shell-snapshots/snapshot-bash-[id].sh
Each snapshot tries to execute ccusage, spawning new Node processes
Process cleanup fails, leading to accumulation

Impact:

System becomes unresponsive due to memory exhaustion
Multiple node.exe processes consume 2-4GB RAM total
Affects both development machines (laptop and PC)

Workaround:

Manually delete shell snapshots: rmdir /S /Q
"%USERPROFILE%.claude\shell-snapshots"
Remove ccusage from global Claude Code settings
Kill Node processes: taskkill /F /IM node.exe

Recommendation:
ccusage may need better process cleanup or compatibility testing with
Claude Code's shell management system.

node_title: [Bug] ccusage statusline causes infinite process spawning loop leading to 100% CPU usage
bodyText:
I can reproduce this issue as well.
The ccusage processes are indeed accumulating as shown in the top screenshot.

My hypothesis and investigation:
I suspected this might be a timing mismatch between ccusage execution speed and statusline request frequency, so I decided to measure both sides:
My measurements:


ccusage statusline execution takes ~10 seconds in my environment



Statusline requests occur much more frequently - about half of the requests come within 1-second intervals when measured over ~100 turn converstation



This timing gap causes new processes to spawn faster than existing ones can complete


Analysis:
Based on my measurements, I think the root cause might be that Claude Code's statusline hook spawns new ccusage processes before previous ones finish executing. Since ccusage takes significantly longer to execute than the statusline refresh rate, processes could accumulate and consume CPU resources.
This could explain the behavior described in the issue - the processes might not be terminating properly because new ones keep getting spawned before the previous ones complete their work.

node_title: Live Blocks not accurate, Limit reached earlier
bodyText:
When the live blocks feature was implemented Anthropic did not vary the token limit considerably. There were small fluctuations in allowable limit but broadly speaking they remained roughly the same. Given that was the case, the limit feature was implemented in such a way that it would set the limit to the largest number of tokens seen previously in any 5 hour session (block).
It appears that Anthropic have done two things in the last month or so:

Reduced limits considerably, from tens (5x) or hundreds (20x) of millions of tokens to just millions (5x) and tens of millions (20x).
Increased the amount by which token limits vary during the day, presumably to better handle user usage patterns and prevent 429 issues.

Anthropic intentionally and pointedly does not allow us to interrogate what the real token limit is, so we have to take a best guess. At the moment, I don't think the implementation here is appropriate any more, due to the changes Anthropic has made.
My suggestion is to limit the lookback period in determining the token limit, perhaps to the last week of usage.

node_title: feat: Show the cost if we were using a different model, say GPT-5
bodyText:
I don't think this is all that valuable because the token use by model, especially for reasoning, is so drastically different.
You're not going to get anywhere near an accurate estimate asking "if I ran this same prompt through gpt-5 or grok 4, what would it have cost".
For example, grok 4 uses much more thinking/reasoning tokens than an anthropic model or gpt-5, you cannot compare token use from one reasoning model and cost it out in another. So I question the value in doing something like this.
To further illustrate this... here's the Cost to Run Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index and you'll see the vast majority of cost is reasoning cost which ccusage would not be able to accurately estimate. This is essentially consistent cost input (same benchmark to the models), and the cost to complete the benchmark, broken down by input/reasoning/output cost.

node_title: feat: Show the cost if we were using a different model, say GPT-5
bodyText:
It’s true that reasoning tokens vary wildly between different models. However, if GPT-5 with its selection for low to high thinking modes is any indicator, this variability is likely to go down in the future.
Also, one could argue that if reasoning tokens skew these comparisons, a tool that could do an apples to apples comparison given the same reasoning token count could be even more valuable.
A statement like
“Claude Opus costs 20% more for my usage than Grok 4, but thinks 30% less (probably)”
has more valuable data than
“Claude costs $15/mil versus Grok 4 $10/mil tokens”
But I’ll leave it at that. This is just user feedback. Please implement if you feel it’s worth your time and long term vision.

node_title: [suggestion]: extracting `total_cost_usd`, record it, and use it for other commands (daily, monthly...)
bodyText:
Implementation Plan: Save Statusline Costs to JSON and Improve Global --mode Option
Overview
Implementing a feature to persist Claude Code's total_cost_usd from statusline to local JSON files, then use this data to enhance cost accuracy in other commands. Also improving the global --mode option to support new modes that prioritize Claude Code's official costs.
Key Implementation Steps
1. Create Cost Storage Module (src/cost-storage.ts)

Function to get cost storage directory: ~/.config/claude/ccusage/costs/ (with XDG support)
Function to save cost data: saveCostData(sessionId, cost, timestamp)
Function to load cost data: loadCostData(sessionId)
Use JSON format: {sessionId}.json with structure:
{
  "sessionId": "xxx",
  "costs": [
    {
      "timestamp": "2025-01-22T10:30:00Z",
      "totalCostUsd": 12.45,
      "source": "statusline"
    }
  ]
}


2. Update Statusline Command (src/commands/statusline.ts)

After receiving hookData.cost?.total_cost_usd, save it to storage
Only save when cost is available and valid
Add --save-cost flag (default: true) for opt-in/out
Minimal performance impact using async non-blocking writes

3. Enhance Cost Mode System

Add new cost modes to existing modes in src/_types.ts:

"cc": Prioritize saved Claude Code costs, fallback to calculated
"max": Return the highest cost from all available sources (CC, ccusage calculated, costUSD)


Update CostModes: ['auto', 'calculate', 'display', 'cc', 'max']
New mode behaviors:

cc: Use saved CC costs → JSONL costUSD → calculate from tokens
max: Calculate all possible costs and return the highest value
auto: Check saved CC costs first, then costUSD, then calculate (enhanced)
Keep existing calculate and display modes unchanged



4. Update Data Loader (src/data-loader.ts)

Modify calculateCostForEntry() to check saved CC costs
Add loadSavedCost() helper to retrieve persisted costs
For max mode: calculate all costs and return highest
Update cost calculation priority for each mode

5. Update All Commands

Ensure all commands (daily, monthly, session, blocks) support new modes
Update shared args to include cc and max in mode choices
Maintain backward compatibility

6. Add Documentation

Update docs/guide/statusline.md with cost saving feature
Document benefits and use cases

7. Add Tests

Test cost storage read/write operations
Test new modes in various scenarios
Ensure no performance regression

Benefits

More accurate cost tracking using Claude Code's official calculations
Accounts for tool usage costs that aren't in token counts
Excludes cancelled branch costs (double ESC) that aren't charged
Maximum cost visibility with new max mode for conservative estimates
Seamless integration with existing commands

Migration & Compatibility

Fully backward compatible
Cost storage is opt-in by default but can be disabled
Gradual improvement as more costs are saved over time
No breaking changes

Updated Implementation Plan (Refined Mode Behaviors)
Key Changes:

Renamed cc → statusline for clarity
max mode: MAX(saved statusline costs, pre-calculated costUSD, token-based calculation) - returns highest value
auto mode: unchanged (pre-calculated costUSD → token-based calculation)
statusline mode: saved statusline costs → pre-calculated costUSD → token-based calculation

Mode Summary:

auto: costUSD → calculate (original behavior)
calculate: tokens only
display: costUSD only
statusline: statusline → costUSD → calculate
max: MAX of all three sources

This addresses the concern that CC costs miss cancelled branches (double ESC), so max provides the highest/most conservative estimate.

node_title: [suggestion]: extracting `total_cost_usd`, record it, and use it for other commands (daily, monthly...)
bodyText:
also i tested cccost, but recently many people including me are migrating to native build version of cc, so we cannot use cccost

Yeah, this statusline hook looks like a good method (at least for now).
I do wonder if this is "accidental" by Anthropic and they'll adjust the hook JSON to return differently for Pro/Max subscribers vs. the paid users (similar to their obvious moves in the jsonl and /cost command). But for now, it looks like a good way to get the costing data.
The downside is of course that actual token use isn't in that data, and has to come from JSONL only.
If the native binary does catch on and become more popular than node version, or if they do remove this hook data, then the preferred method might be a mini proxy server that runs locally and collects the exact token counts from each request/return payload.
